word.description: {豉} is *salted fermented beans* and {油} is *oil* (also used in {香油} *sesame oil*), so {豉油} is *salted fermented bean oil*.

description:
[Soy sauce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soy_sauce) is brewed from fermented soybean paste.

**History**

Soy sauce originated in China over two thousand years ago as a way to stretch the use of salt (a prized commodity in ancient China, heavily taxed and smuggled).

word.description: {生} is *life* (in a *fresh* sense, similar to the word for *lettuce*, {生菜} *life vegetable*), and {抽} is short for another word for *soy sauce* {抽油}, *smoky sauce* or *smoky oil*. So {生抽} is *fresh soy sauce* or *life smoky oil*.

images.place: Chinatown Supermarket, South Salt Lake, Utah

description: Light [Soy sauce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soy_sauce), specifically Chinese light soy sauce (different from Japanese light soy sauce), is a thinner and lighter, but saltier, soy sauce, that is the default soy sauce used in cooking.

word.description: {甜} is *sweet*, {豉} is *salted fermented beans* and {油} is *oil* (also used in {香油} *sesame oil*), so {豉油} is *sweet salted fermented bean oil*.

description: Sweet soy sauce conists mostly of wheat, so it's also known as [Tianmian sauce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tianmian_sauce), which means *sweet flour sauce*, and not suprisingly very thick, so it's also known as *sweet wheat paste*.

word.description: {蘑菇} is *mushroom* and {老抽} is *dark soy sauce*, so 蘑菇老抽 is *mushroom dark soy sauce*.

description: [Mushroom-flavored soy sauce](https://thewoksoflife.com/mushroom-flavored-dark-soy-sauce/) is a [dark soy sauce](https://thewoksoflife.com/dark-soy-sauce/), typically used, sparingly, to add darker color to sauces.

word.description: {香} is *fragrant* (the same {香} used in *Hong Kong* {香港}), and {油} is *oil* (the same {油} used in *soy sauce* {豉油}), so {香油} is *sesame oil*.

description:
[Sesame oil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sesame_oil) is made from toasted sesame seeds.

**Tips**

When shopping, look for pure sesame oil, not blended, and not cold pressed sesame oil. When cooking, apply sesame oil at the end or after just before serving, as high temperature destroys the flavor.
